column1: Tamworth is a city and the administrative centre of the North Western region of New South Wales
column2: Australia. Situated on the Peel River within the local government area of Tamworth Regional Council
column3: it is the largest and most populated city in the North Western region
column4: with a population of 42
column6: making it the second largest inland city in New South Wales. Tamworth is 318 km (198 mi) from the Queensland border
column7: and it is located almost midway between Brisbane and Sydney.

column1: The city is known as the "First Town of Lights"
column2: being the first place in Australia to use electric street lights in 1888.

column1: Tamworth is also famous as the "Country Music Capital of Australia"
column2: annually hosting the Tamworth Country Music Festival in late January; the second-biggest country music festival in the world
column3: after Nashville. The city is recognised as the National Equine Capital of Australia because of the high number of equine events held in the city and the construction of the world-class Australian Equine and Livestock Events Centre
column4: the biggest of its kind in the Southern Hemisphere.

column1: The first record of correctional facilities being established in Tamworth was on 17 December 1864 when the local Police Magistrate was appointed as the Visiting Justice at the Tawmorth Gaol. A gaoler and sheriff were appointed in 1868. At the commencement of 1920
column2: there were 11 prisoners detained. During that year
column3: 201 prisoners were received with 183 discharged leaving 29 in prison by 31 December 1920. Almost 20 per cent of the prisoners were aged under 21 years. The Tamworth Gaol ceased to exist on 25 March 1943
column4: and this was ratified by a proclamation from 8 April 1943.

column1: Prior to its opening as an adult male correctional centre in 1991
column2: the facility (known variously as the Tamworth Institution for Boys
column4: and Endeavour House) was a male juvenile justice centre that pre–dated the establishment of the Kariong Youth Correctional Centre which opened in September 1991.

column1: 1818 – Explorer John Oxley passes through the area on his exploration mission. Names the river that now runs through the town: Peel River
column2: after British Prime Minister Robert Peel.
namely Joseph Brown's 'Wallamoul' and William Dangar's 'Waldoo'. The exploring expedition led by Major Mitchell visited 'Wallamoul' in December 1831 on its way to the north-west.

column1: 1834 – 6000 sheep of the Australian Agriculture Company were the first to be brought to the Tamworth region.
1851 – The white population of the village of Tamworth was 254.
1852 – John Barnes built the Royal Oak Hotel.
1888 – Power station opened and enables the beginning of electric street lighting. The first electric streetlights in Australia.
1918 – A pedestal is unveiled as a memorial to the discovery of Tamworth district.
1926 – An anchor from the HM survey ship Sealark is erected on the pedestal.
1935 - Radio 2TM began broadcasting. Tamworth's first radio station.
1947 – East-West Airlines was established in Tamworth

column1: 2006 – In December the Tamworth Regional Council voted 6 to 3 against an offer from the Federal Government to take part in a one-year trial rural refugee resettlement programme; the majority of these refugees would be Sudanese escaping civil war in their homeland. Mayor of Tamworth
column2: Cr James Treloar
column3: argued that the refugees being resettled were tuberculous and criminal. The decision resulted in national and international media attention on the town. The public outrage unleashed by his comments and the summary decision to reject the refugees forced a reversal of the bill one month later
column4: and Tamworth will now take part in the resettling program.

column1: 2008 – The Australian Equine and Livestock Events Centre opened in September.
2016 – Tamworth hosted the annual City vs Country Origin rugby league match at Scully Park Regional Sporting Precinct.
2020 - Tamworth became the New Zealand Warriors Temporary Training and Isolation facility During the COVID-19 Pandemic
Tamworth is located on the western side of the Great Dividing Range
column2: on the banks of the Peel River
column3: about 420 km (260 mi) north of Sydney on the New England Highway
column4: and 280 km (170 mi) inland from Port Macquarie on the Oxley Highway. The city is situated at a narrow point on the Peel River floodplain
column5: nestled at the base of the Wentworth Mounds
column6: a spur of the Moonbi Range
column7: where the Northwest Slopes rise to the Northern Tablelands. The elevation is around 400 m (1
column8: 300 ft) AHD. The Peel River runs southeast to northwest through Tamworth. The main city centre is on the northeast bank
column9: between the river and the Wentworth Mounds
column10: which rise to heights of 800 m (2
column12: towering over the city. The southwest bank is much flatter
column13: and the city's suburbs sprawl to the south. Water for residents and the town's industry is supplied by Chaffey Dam
column14: 44 km (27 mi) south east of the city.

column1: Tamworth has a warm climate with hot summers and mild winters. It is included in the rainfall records and weather forecast region of the North West Slopes or the North West Slopes and Plains division of the Bureau of Meteorology forecasts. Under the Köppen climate classification scheme
column2: Tamworth has a humid subtropical climate (Cfa).

column1: Temperatures exceed 35 °C (95 °F) on around 20–25 days a year
column2: but over the past few years have exceeded this number substantially. The average maximum temperature is 33 °C (91 °F) in the summer
column4: the mean annual rainfall is 673.2 mm (26.50 in). Winters are mild or sometimes even warm by day
column5: and cool to cold by night. Daytime temperatures hover around 16–17 °C (61–63 °F) and occasionally make it to 20
column7: Tamworth recorded a new record high of 42.5 °C (108.5 °F)
column8: eclipsing the previous record by 0.5 of a degree
column9: but one year later on 3 January 2014
column10: Tamworth broke this record yet again by almost 3 degrees
column11: recording 45.1 °C (113.2 °F). It has since broken this record again
column12: recording 45.9 °C (114.6 °F) on 12 February 2017.Rainfall is experienced all year round
column13: with summer storms providing occasional heavy downpours. Tamworth's rainy season
column14: in the early months of a new year (particularly January) can result in major flooding. Snow is very rare in Tamworth
column15: but does occasionally occur in the surrounding higher villages such as Nundle (although far from reliable). Frosts are not seldom. On 28 and 29 November 2008
column18: and the surrounding area received torrential rain that caused severe flooding and led to the area being declared a natural disaster area.

column1: Tamworth is recognised nationally as the sporting horse capital of Australia and is the headquarters of Dave Manchon
column2: as well as for three major equine associations: CHA
column3: ABCRA and AQHA. Many of the Australia's most important equine events take place in Tamworth. Various international

column1: Tamworth is best known for hosting the Country Music Festival. The Festival is held over a period of 10 days from Friday to Sunday in mid to late January each year and sometimes includes Australia Day. It is the second biggest country music festival in the world. The festival has many times been counted among the world's top ten music festivals. In 2007
column2: Forbes rated it as number 8 of the World's Coolest Music Festivals. It features thousands of Australian and international country music artists performing live shows 24 hours a day. Each year
column4: 000 people pass through Tamworth for the festival
column6: 000 staying for a substantial duration of the festival
column7: with some camping along the banks of the Peel River.

column1: Tamworth was the first town in Australia to light its streets by municipally generated electritown in 1888. A larger power station was established in 1923 at a site in Marius Street
column2: East Tamworth due to the high demand of electritown and the main building was demolished in 1982. The Tamworth Power Station Museum's purpose is to tell the story of the town's role in the development of electric street lighting
column3: from the early days of oil lamps in 1876 and gas lamps in 1882
column4: through to the installation of the first electric lights in November 1888. The museum has one of Australia's largest collections of early 20th century electrical appliances.

column4: Velocette and Laverda. The museum holds an example of the limited edition MV Agusta F4 Serie Oro.
